notes: Works best on porous materials
Requires clean, dry surfaces
Expands slightly during cure
Requires moisture for curing in some formulations

fasteners.name: Two-component epoxy

notes: High strength
Requires clean and abraded surfaces
Two-part mixing required

fasteners.curing_time: 5 minutes to 24 hours depending on formulation

notes: Bonds quickly
Brittle under shear and vibration
Not ideal for large gaps
Designed for structural assembly
Often used in building envelopes
Fast setting
Poor high-temperature performance

fasteners.name: Contact cement

notes: Apply to both surfaces and allow to flash
Immediate bond on contact

fasteners.curing_time: immediate bond after contact; full strength in 24+ hours

fasteners.name: Silicone sealant

notes: Not structural
Excellent for movement joints

fasteners.curing_time: 24 hours to several days (skin time within hours)

notes: Paintable
Used for interior/exterior joints with limited movement
Good for light bonding and laminating
Can be messy; ventilation required
Removable bonds on paper
Primarily for craft/bookbinding

fasteners.name: Marine epoxy

notes: Formulated for submerged/outdoor conditions
Very good environmental resistance

fasteners.curing_time: hours to days depending on formulation

notes: Designed to set under tile loads; use appropriate mortar/setting material
Formulated to resist foot traffic and shear loads
Designed for interior surfaces; removable with effort

fasteners.name: PVC pipe cement

notes: Solvent-welds PVC pipes; requires correct primer in some systems

fasteners.curing_time: minutes to 24 hours (initial set then full cure)

notes: Formulated for ABS solvent-welding
High temperature CPVC variants available
Formulated to remain stable at elevated temperatures
Designed to hold gaskets in place during assembly

fasteners.name: Glass adhesive

notes: Special formulations for optical clarity and thermal stress

surface_prep: use primer for some glass types

fasteners.name: Metal epoxy

notes: Formulated for metal repair and bonding

fasteners.curing_time: minutes to hours depending on formula

notes: Formulated to remain flexible on textiles
Low mechanical strength; used for cushioning assemblies

fasteners.name: Pressure-sensitive adhesive (PSA)

notes: Bond forms on applied pressure; includes tapes and labels

fasteners.curing_time: immediate tack; full ageing over days

notes: General-purpose; leaves residue on removal
Good for mounting lightweight items; some high-bond variants exist
High strength, reversible; performance depends on material and coating
Threads designed for wood gripping; pilot hole often recommended
Simple fastening for wood; limited tensile capacity
Permanent mechanical fastener for sheet materials
Alignment pins; often used with glue for strength
Fuses plastic; strong when correctly performed

fasteners.name: Metal welding

notes: Structural joining method; requires skilled operator

special_conditions: Skilled procedure; heat effects on materials

notes: Electrical/mechanical joints but low structural strength; requires flux
Square neck prevents rotation when embedded in wood
Large structural screw for heavy wood connections
Paired with bolts to clamp materials
Resists loosening under vibration
Self-tapping threads for thin metal
Brittle steel; not for structural loads
Coated for outdoor weather resistance
Forms its own threads in metal or plastic
Small head for aesthetic finishes
Used for trim and light woodworking
Large head for securing shingles outdoors
Hardened steel for driving into masonry
Expands to grip holes in masonry
Provides right-angle reinforcement
Used for flat reinforcement and joining
Strengthens internal corners in frames or boxes
Nylon loop fastener; cut to remove
Holds pipes securely to surfaces or fixtures
Ensures tight seal around hoses

questions.text: What is the first surface it is intended for?
What is the second surface it is intended for?
What type of mechanical strength is required?
Will the connection be exposed to weather or moisture?
Does the connection need to be permanent or removable?
What is the acceptable curing/drying time?
What load will the connection experience?
Does it require chemical or corrosion resistance?
Is flexibility required in the cured state?
Is the application vertical or overhead?
Are there health concerns (fumes, food safety)?

What is the size of the area to be joined?
(small <20 cm², medium <1 m², large >1 m²)

suggestion_rules.suggestion: Consider stainless steel bolts for superior corrosion resistance
Use marine-grade (316) stainless steel for saltwater applications
Zinc-plated or galvanized fasteners recommended for moisture protection
Use lock washers, lock nuts, or threadlocker to prevent loosening
Consider coated or stainless steel fasteners for chemical resistance
Use stainless steel or coated screws for outdoor applications
Pre-drill pilot holes to prevent splitting, especially near edges
For vertical/overhead application, consider using tape or clamps during curing
Ensure adequate ventilation and consider low-VOC or food-safe options
Note: Most adhesives require curing time. Consider mechanical fasteners for immediate use
Requires specialized equipment and trained operator
Consider joint design and material thickness for optimal weld strength
Welding produces fumes - ensure proper ventilation and PPE
